Award.AwardTitle: DIMEs: Immersing Teachers and Students in Virtual Engineering Internships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) outline the science competencies students should demonstrate through their K-12 years and represent a commitment to integrate engineering design into the structure of science education. However, achieving this new ideal of teaching and learning will require new curricular and pedagogical supports for teachers as well as new and time-efficient assessment methods. This project will provide such curricular and pedagogical support by developing and evaluating teacher-ready curricular Digital Internship Modules for Engineering (DIMEs). DIMES will be designed to support middle school science teachers in providing students with experiences that require students to use engineering design practices and science understanding to solve a real-world problem, thereby promoting a robust understanding of science and engineering, and motivating students to increased interest in science and engineering. The modules will also assess students' ability to apply their science knowledge in solving the engineering problem, thereby providing teachers with actionable data about the depth of their students' science and engineering understanding. The DIMEs will be environments where students work as interns at a simulated engineering firm.

The Digital Internship Modules for Engineering will provide immersive experiences that simultaneously serve as learning and assessment opportunities. DIMEs will assess not only whether students understand NGSS science and engineering concepts, but also whether they can use them in the context of real-world problem solving. Teachers will orchestrate DIMEs using a custom-designed teacher interface that will show student work, auto-generated assessments, and reports on each student's learning progress. This project will build on prior work on NSF-funded computer-based STEM learning environments called epistemic games. Epistemic games are computer role-playing games that have been successfully used in both undergraduate engineering courses and informal settings for K-12 populations to teach students to think like STEM professionals, thereby preparing them to solve 21st century problems. The project will create six ten-day activities, two each in Physical Science, Life Science and Earth Science units that are typically taught in middle school. An iterative research and design process is used to conduct pilot tests of the six DIMEs in local classrooms, field test a beta version of each DIME with 15 teachers and up to 1500 students in national classrooms, and then implement final versions of each DIME in research trials with 30 teachers and up to 3000 students in national classrooms. By bringing cutting-edge developments in learning science and undergraduate engineering education to middle school STEM education, the project aims to improve educational practice, and enhance assessment of learning outcomes in middle school science classroom settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project is to provide middleschool students with immersive experiences at the intersection of science and engineering through the development and study of a suite of six Digital Engineering Internships (DIMEs). As a model for how engineering may be meaningfully integrated with science instruction, each unit is experienced by students as a simulated virtual engineering internship (VEI) in which students apply science knowledge to design solutions to a compelling real-world problem. Through its integration with a nationally published curriculum, DIMEs are in use by over 500,000 students nationwide as of the 2019-2020 academic year. DIMEs' alignment with NGSS has facilitated uptake by meeting educator needs and provides an innovative way to broaden access to engineering learning experiences. 

In conjunction with the VEI model, students interact in varied and complex ways with a suite of digital resources, which enables an authentically three-dimensional learning and assessment experience. For example, each unit features a custom digital design tool, where students can design, test, and iterate on their solutions. Units also share an internship interface, through which students receive daily messages from their fictional Internship Director and submit and recieve design solutions for feedback. Using a learning analytics model developed through the grant, DIMEs leverage the rich data generated through student interactions with these resources to assess student understanding of NGSS science concepts and engineering practices, and how they use them in the context of real-world problem solving.

Outcomes

Positive learning gains and dispositional changes among study participants (n=2036) offer strong evidence of promise for this model. The table below presents the resulting mean difference values, the associated effect sizes (Cohen's d), and two-sided p-values for pre-post changes. We see medium effect-size growth across several areas, which largely map to explicit supports within the VEIs. Class-time is devoted to learning new conceptual material, as well as defining and examining the role of criteria and tradeoffs in an engineering design problem. However, other areas show little/no growth. For instance, students show small growth in Relevant Prior Concepts, which is understandable as these concepts are not addressed directly in instruction. Further, students' comfort with data analysis showed little change despite engagement with this science and engineering practice over the course of the VEI. This suggests a need for more explicit support for this science and engineering practice beyond the implicit learning that occurs through classroom activities. Current iterations of the units have taken this suggestion into account. We also see a very small, but statistically significant, decrease in student Fascination with Engineering Design, as measured by a modification of the STEM Fascination scale from the Activation Lab suite of measures. While quite small, this decrease is surprising and merits further investigation.

The digital engineering internships created through this grant provide a model for integrating engineering into middle school science curricula. Insights from our study of DIMEs suggest promise for: the simulated internship model, pedagogical approaches to support authentic student engagement in multiple iterations through the engineering design cycle, and the automated formative assessment of engineering practices through multi-dimensional performance. 

We believe that the assessment and analytics model developed through this work will serve as a model for assessing science and engineering practices. In particular, our forthcoming article describing how we operationalized for assessment purposes the construct of optimization as a science and engineering practice has clear potential to ground other measurement and assessment efforts of engineering practices. By creating a tractable articulation of the somewhat amorphous construct of optimization, and using DIMES as a case study to define and capture specific student behaviors that might count as evidence of facility with the practice, we hope to contribute to the field?s ability to systematically study and support the learning of science and engineering practices.

Findings also suggest that our approach to learning analytics, in conjunction with the curricular affordances of multiple iterations through the design cycle (providing a rich and nuanced data set for the analytics algorithms to work on), has the potential to serve as an exemplar for the growing body of efforts seeking to leverage technology to support formative assessment of complex, multi-dimensional learning experiences. Along these lines we also hope to contribute to the learning analytics and data science communities? ongoing efforts to develop principles for how digital data sets may be best structured so that they more readily afford production of meaningful inferences.
